questions.question: A mother comes with her child who has papules on the extensor surfaces of the skin, which resolve with the administration of vitamins A and C and essential amino acids. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: surfaces, which can improve with vitamin A supplementation. The resolution of symptoms with the administration of vitamins A and C, along with essential amino acids, is consistent with this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: Option B - Rickets: This is a condition resulting from vitamin D deficiency, leading to weak and soft bones in children. Symptoms include bone deformities and growth retardation, but it does not typically present with papules on the extensor surfaces. Option C - Kwashiorkor: This is a form of protein-energy malnutrition characterized by edema, irritability, and skin changes. It usually involves more generalized symptoms of malnutrition rather than isolated papules that resolve with vitamins and amino acids. Option D - Marasmus: This is another form of severe malnutrition caused by a deficiency in caloric intake, leading to severe weight loss and muscle wasting. It does not present with papules but rather with severe overall wasting. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Pages 725-727 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine, 2nd edition, Pages 30,31 https://www.google.com/url?q=https://openi.nlm.nih.gov/detailedres ult?img%3DPMC2854467_IJO-58-175-g001%26query%3Dphrynoderma%26it%3Dxg%26lic%3Dby%26req%3D4 %26npos%3D1&sa=D&source=docs&ust=1725598974523732&usg=AOvVaw2pmVc81oBk4rcdkVUo-YxR

questions.question: Which of the following foods has the maximum biological value?
questions.explanation: their high biological value. They are considered a complete protein source as they contain all essential amino acids in optimal ratios. Egg protein is highly bioavailable and contains important nutrients such as vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. Egg Importance Eggs are highly nutritious and rich in protein, essential vitamins, & minerals. They support muscle building, brain health, and overall wellness. NPU of egg is 96 (~ almost equal to 100) Rule of 6 6 grams of protein 6 grams of fat 60 calories per large egg 6 essential vitamins (A, B2, B12, D, E, K) 60 grams average weight Others: 6x5=30 mg Calcium 6x0.25=1.5mg Iron Eggs are easy to digest and have high bioavailability, meaning the body can efficiently absorb and utilise the protein. Net Protein Utilization (NPU): Digestibility coefficient (external indicator) x Biological value (internal indicator) / 100 Percentage of the ingested nitrogen retained in the body 1 gm protein = 6.25gm nitrogen NPU Indian diet: 50-80 Pulses (Option A): Pulses, such as lentils, chickpeas, and beans, are a rich source of plant-based protein. While they provide essential amino acids, they are generally considered to have lower biological value compared to animal-based proteins. This is because pulses are deficient in one or more essential amino acids, particularly methionine. Soybean (Option B): While soybean protein is of higher quality among plant-based sources, it still does not match the BV of animal-based proteins due to slightly lower digestibility and bioavailability. Milk (Option C): Milk has a high BV (around 85–90) because it contains all essential amino acids in a good ratio and is easily digestible. Milk protein, particularly casein and whey, is of high quality and supports tissue repair and growth effectively. However, its biological value is slightly lower than egg. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 725, 741-43, 745 IAPSM textbook of Community medicine, 2nd edition, Page 41 A review on plant-based proteins from soybean: Health benefits and soy product development - ScienceDirect

questions.question: Which of the following food items contains the lowest amount of iron?
questions.explanation: non-haem iron. Haem iron Haem iron is better absorbed than non-haem iron. Found in liver (Option A ruled out) , meat, poultry, and fish. Promotes absorption of non-haem iron in plant foods eaten concurrently. Non-Haem iron: It is found in plant-based foods such as cereals, green leafy vegetables (Option B ruled out) , legumes (Option C ruled out) , nuts, oilseeds, jaggery, and dried fruits. Additional Iron Sources : Cooking in iron vessels can significantly contribute to dietary iron in some areas. Iron Content in Milk : Low in all mammalian species. (Option D) Breast milk contains less than 0.2 mg/dL but has good bioavailability. Bioavailability and Absorption Inhibitors : Non-haem iron absorption is hindered by phytates, oxalates, carbonates, phosphates, and dietary fibre. Foods like milk, eggs, and tea also inhibit iron absorption. Indian vegetarian diets often contain high levels of these inhibitors (e.g., phytates in bran, phosphates in egg yolk, tannin in tea, and oxalates in vegetables). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Pg. 737

questions.question: Which statement is correct regarding the reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the RDA ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Weight 55 kgs Explanation: The reference woman represents the average healthy woman's nutritional needs and is used as a standard for setting the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) . This reference is crucial for determining the nutrient requirements of the general population. Weight 55 kgs : The reference woman is typically assumed to have a body weight of 55 kg (121 lbs). This value is used to determine the average energy and nutrient requirements. Height 1.73 m (Option B) : While height is a factor in determining nutritional needs, the reference woman is generally assumed to have a height of around 1.60 m (not 1.73 m). Works 10 hours/day (Option C) : The reference woman is not assumed to work for a specific number of hours each day. Nutritional requirements can vary depending on physical activity, but the reference is typically for a woman with moderate activity levels. Age of 18-25 years (Option D) : The reference woman is not specifically limited to this age range. Nutritional needs are assessed based on a range of factors, including age, but the reference woman is generally used as an average for adult women (not limited to a specific age group). Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 747

questions.question: What is the most relevant information that should be obtained from the medical history of a patient from Chhattisgarh who is experiencing gradual muscle weakness and spasms in the legs, and exhibits only motor impairment upon examination?

options.A: History of similar illness in the past

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) History of diet. Explanation: The patient is from Chhattisgarh , a region known for outbreaks of Lathyrism , a neurological disorder caused by the consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal) . Lathyrism is characterized by gradual-onset spastic paraparesis (muscle weakness and spasms in the legs), with only motor impairment and no sensory loss. The toxin β -N-oxalyl-L- α , β -diaminopropionic acid ( β -ODAP) in Khesari dal causes upper motor neuron (UMN) damage , leading to progressive spastic paralysis . Features of Lathyrism: Feature Findings Cause Excessive consumption of Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal) Region Endemic in Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, Bihar, Odisha Symptoms Gradual-onset spastic paraparesis , hyperreflexia Sensory Involvement Absent (pure motor disorder) Prevention Dietary restriction, government bans on Khesari dal History of similar illness in the past (Option A): While a history of similar illness may be relevant in some cases, this patient's symptoms are more likely due to a dietary issue rather than a recurrent illness. History of fever (Option B): Fever could indicate an infection or inflammation but isn't the primary concern given the gradual onset of symptoms . The absence of fever makes this less relevant in the current context. History of vaccination (Option C): While vaccination is important for preventing diseases like poliomyelitis , in this case, the gradual onset of muscle weakness and spasms suggests a nutritional or metabolic cause rather than a vaccine-preventable disease. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 701, 702 Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 759

questions.question: Which of the following factors can contribute to the development of malnutrition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Infectious diseases Explanation: Infectious diseases significantly contribute to malnutrition by increasing metabolic demands, reducing appetite, impairing nutrient absorption, and causing nutrient loss. Common infections such as diarrhea, tuberculosis, parasitic infections, and respiratory infections lead to weight loss, muscle wasting, and stunting. Recurrent infections create a vicious cycle where malnutrition weakens immunity, leading to more infections. Role of Infectious Diseases in Malnutrition: Infection Effect on Nutrition Diarrheal diseases Causes fluid and nutrient loss , leading to dehydration and malabsorption. Tuberculosis (TB) Increases catabolism (muscle breakdown) , leading to weight loss. Parasitic infections (e.g., hookworm, giardiasis) Causes iron deficiency anemia, protein loss, and malabsorption . Measles Leads to vitamin A deficiency , impairing immune function. Child rearing (Option A): While child rearing practices can influence nutrition (e.g., breastfeeding practices, introduction of complementary foods), it does not directly cause malnutrition in the same way infections can. Poor child rearing practices may contribute, but they are not a primary factor. Food habits (Option C): Food habits certainly play a role in nutrition, but they alone do not directly cause malnutrition unless they are extreme (e.g., insufficient intake of essential nutrients). In general, food habits are more of a contributing factor rather than a primary cause. Socioeconomic factors (Option D): Socioeconomic factors, such as poverty, can significantly affect access to adequate food and healthcare, contributing to malnutrition. However, socioeconomic factors are broader and often contribute in conjunction with other factors like food habits and infectious diseases. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 27, Page 626 Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 25, Page 708, 709

questions.question: With regards to the pasteurization of milk, which of the following tests is not related?
questions.explanation: of milk. It is a test used to detect the presence of starch in a substance. It involves adding iodine solution to the sample, and if starch is present, the solution will turn blue-black. Incorrect Choices: Phosphatase test (Option A): The phosphatase test is indeed related to the pasteurization of milk. Phosphatase is an enzyme naturally present in raw milk but is inactivated during the pasteurization process. By measuring the activity of phosphatase in milk, it can be determined if proper pasteurization has occurred. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the phosphatase test is directly related to pasteurization. Standard plate count (Option C): The standard plate count is also related to the pasteurization of milk. It is a test used to determine the total number of viable microorganisms present in milk. By assessing the microbial load, the effectiveness of pasteurization in reducing bacterial contamination can be evaluated. This option is incorrect as the standard plate count is directly associated with assessing the pasteurization process. Methylene blue reduction test (Option D): The methylene blue reduction test is used to assess the bacteriological quality of milk and the efficiency of pasteurization. It evaluates the reduction of methylene blue dye by the metabolic activity of microorganisms in milk. This test helps determine if pasteurization has effectively inhibited bacterial growth. Therefore, this option is incorrect as the methylene blue reduction test is directly related to pasteurization. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 723

questions.question: If Bajra is mixed with black seeds, what is used to separate them?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - 20% salt water A 20% salt water solution creates a density that makes black seeds sink, while Bajra seeds stay afloat, making the separation easy. Ergotism: Ergot is a fungus (Claviceps purpurea) that infects food grains such as bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat during their flowering stages. Consumption of ergot-infested grains can lead to ergotism , characterised by acute symptoms such as nausea, repeated vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness lasting up to 24 to 48 hours . In chronic cases, ergotism may cause painful cramps in limbs and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries . Modern high-yielding varieties of bajra are more susceptible to ergot infestation. Infested grains can be removed in 20% salt water, hand-picking, or air floatation. The upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids in food material is 0.05 mg per 100 grams. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 772

questions.question: An 8-month-old baby on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of vitamin A to be administered to the baby?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - 100,000 IU orally For infants aged 6-11 months, the recommended dose of vitamin A to treat deficiency is 100,000 IU administered orally. This dosing is based on WHO guidelines for vitamin A supplementation in children to prevent and treat deficiency, which is crucial for proper immune function, vision, and overall health. <6 months 6 months-1 year > 1 year Day 0 50000 IU 1 lakh IU 2 Lac IU Day 1 50000 IU 1 lakh IU 2 Lac IU Day 2 50000 IU 1 lakh IU 2 Lac IU Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Pg 706

questions.question: Highest sodium content is present in which of the following foods:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer C - Canned soup Canned soup is known to have a very high sodium content because salt is often added as a preservative and for flavor enhancement. Sodium levels in canned soups can vary but are often significantly higher than in fresh or minimally processed foods. Micronutrients: Required in small amounts from a fraction of milligrams to several grams. Micronutrients consist of vitamins and minerals. Minerals classification: Major Minerals (PYQ): Calcium, Phosphorous, Sodium, Potassium, Magnesium Trace Elements: Required In Quantities Less Than A Few Milligrams/Day Eg Iron, lodine, Fluorine, Zinc, Copper, Cobalt, Chromium, Manganese, Molybdenum, Selenium, Silicon, Nickel, Tin Trace Contaminants With No Known Function: Lead, Mercury, Barium, Boron, Aluminum Sugar cane, barley, and fresh fruit juices (Options A, B, and D): naturally contain very little sodium Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3678455/

questions.question: What is the likely reason for the food poisoning experienced by the worker in the groundnut factory who consumed spoiled groundnuts that were stored in the facility?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer D - Aflatoxins The likely reason for food poisoning in a worker who consumed spoiled groundnuts stored in the facility is: Aflatoxins Aflatoxins are toxic compounds produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus , fungi that grow on improperly stored food items such as groundnuts (peanuts), grains, and nuts in warm and humid conditions. Aflatoxicosis: Clinical features Features of hepatotoxicity (jaundice, hepatomegaly) Hepatocellular carcinoma Causative agent Infestation of Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus over stored rice, wheat, and corn Produce mycotoxins: aflatoxin B1 & G1 (both are hepatotoxic & carcinogenic) Risk factors Storage temperature of 11 to 37 degree Celsius Moisture content >16% Prevention Educating people Moisture content <10% during storage Beta oxalyl amino alanine (Option A): a neurotoxic compound in certain plants like Lathyrus sativus seeds, leads to Lathyrism when consumed excessively over time. It is not associated with groundnuts. Smoke inhalation (Option B): While exposure to smoke may cause health problems, it does not explain the specific symptoms of food poisoning experienced by the worker. Sanguinarine (Option C): is an alkaloid found in certain plants, including bloodroot and other members of the Papaveraceae family. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, page 771,772

questions.question: What vitamin deficiency leads to xerophthalmia, a condition characterized by dryness of the eyes?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Vitamin A Explanation: Vitamin A deficiency is the primary cause of xerophthalmia, a condition that includes dry eyes and can progress to night blindness and corneal damage if untreated. Vitamin A plays a crucial role in maintaining the health of the cornea. Vitamin B (Option B) : is incorrect because vitamin B deficiencies, like B1, B6, or B12, do not cause xerophthalmia. These deficiencies are linked to neurological and hematological issues, not eye-related conditions. Vitamin C (Option C) : is incorrect because vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, poor wound healing, and skin problems, but not xerophthalmia. Vitamin D (Option D) : is incorrect because vitamin D deficiency primarily leads to rickets in children or osteomalacia in adults, conditions that affect bone health, not the eyes. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 706

questions.question: You are administering vitamin A supplements to an 8-month-old infant for two consecutive days. What is the recommended dose?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 100,000 IU Explanation: For infants 6-11 months old , the recommended dose of Vitamin A supplementation is 100,000 IU for two consecutive days. This is part of national immunization programs aimed at preventing Vitamin A deficiency, which can cause blindness and increase the risk of other infections. 25,000 IU (Option A) : is incorrect because 25,000 IU is the recommended dose for children aged 12-59 months, not for infants under one year. 50,000 IU (Option B) : is incorrect because 50,000 IU is not the standard dose for infants under 1 year. The appropriate dose for infants aged 6-11 months is 100,000 IU . 200,000 IU (Option D) : is incorrect because this dose is generally used for children aged 1-5 years, and is too high for an infant aged 6-11 months. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, Edition 26, Page 706

questions.question: A poor farmer with a history of successive crop failure develops progressive spastic paraparesis, signs of upper motor neuron paralysis, and gait instability. Name the toxin responsible for this condition.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine Explanation: The condition in the given case scenario is called Lathyrism, which is due to the toxin beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine present in Lathyrus seeds. Lathyrism: Causative agent Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months Clinical features Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins Two-stick stage: will need crutches Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in. Treatment Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day Banning the crop Toxin removal Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried. Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater. Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same. Educating people. Bringing socio-economic changes. Aflatoxin (Option A): They are toxins produced by Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus and cause a condition called Aflatoxicosis. It is derived from infested grains and contaminated groundnuts. B1 and G1 are hepatotoxic and carcinogenic. Ergot alkaloids (Option C): They cause ergotism. They are derived from infested grains which are stored for a longer duration. They cause nausea, vomiting, and dizziness which may last for up to 24-48 hours. Sometimes it can cause peripheral gangrene and painful leg cramps. Fusarium toxin (Option D): It can cause contamination of sorghum. Rice is also considered as a substrate for this toxin.

questions.question: Who is responsible for counseling and providing information to the patient, a 30-week primigravida experiencing reduced vision at night, who has been avoiding certain fruits during her pregnancy due to concerns about their potential abortifacient effects?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) ASHA Explanation: Although all of the above given can do this job but single best answer is ASHA Worker The pregnant woman is likely to be suffering from Vitamin A deficiency due to poor intake of foods rich in vitamin A. The primary duty of the ASHA worker is to go for home visits and to counsel regarding sanitation, nutrition , living conditions, and family welfare services. She helps in mobilizing the community to access health care facilities available at PHC/Anganwadi/sub-center. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) ASHA is a woman (married, divorced, or widowed) resident of the village, aged 25-45 years, with education up to 8th grade. Population Norm for ASHA The general norm is 1 ASHA per 1000 population. In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, this may be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation. Role and Responsibilities of ASHA Health Activist: Create awareness and provide information on health determinants, existing services, and the importance of health and family welfare. Counselor : Provide counseling on birth preparedness, safe delivery, and family planning. Mobilizer: Help the community access health services, such as immunizations, sanitation, and nutrition. Provider: Offer basic care for common illnesses and first-aid, and act as a depot for essential medications. Community Engagement: Work with village health committees and panchayats for planning and awareness. Specific Responsibilities of ASHA Promote health and sanitation practices. Advise on child care, immunization, and reproductive health. Assist with family planning and treatment of minor ailments. Mobilize pregnant women and children to health services Provide basic medical care and support for diarrhea, fever, and tuberculosis (under DOTS). Serve as a depot holder for essential drugs and medical supplies. Role and Integration with Anganwadi The Anganwadi worker helps guide ASHA, particularly in organizing Health Day activities, mobilizing village women and children, and promoting nutrition and health education. Role and Integration with ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) ANMs guide ASHA in areas like immunization, safe pregnancy, and health education, and assist in organizing Health Days. ANMs also help with training and monitor ASHA's performance. ANM (Option A): ANM ensures thorough training of the ASHA worker. AWW (Option B): They are part-time workers. She undergoes training for 4 months in various sectors like health, nutrition, and child development. Trained birth attendant (Option D): They ensure safe delivery, monitor maternal and fetal well-being, promote a positive birthing experience by reducing stress and anxiety during labor, promote exclusive breastfeeding, and are trained to identify and rectify any labor complications. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 989,990

questions.question: In a village, it is observed that several farmers have crossed gait and use a stick for support to stand up and walk. Due to poor yield from farms, they consume meals containing rice and pulses only. Supplementing their diet with which of the following vitamins could have prevented this?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Vitamin C Explanation: The people in this scenario are likely to be suffering from Neurolathyrism . As a method of prevention , the diet should be supplemented with Vitamin C 500-1000 mg/day for 1 week. Lathyrism: Causative agent Beta-oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA) present in Lathyrus sativus Significant exposure : >30% inclusion in diet over 2-6 months Clinical features Latent stage: preventive can be best implemented here No stick stage: most common point of diagnosis One-stick stage: muscular stiffness begins Two-stick stage: will need crutches Crawler stage: muscular atrophy sets in. Treatment Vitamin C prophylaxis: 500-1000 mg per day Banning the crop Toxin removal Steeping method: soaking in hot water for 2 hours, drained and sun-dried. Parboiling: overnight soaking in limewater. Genetic approach: selecting variants with less BOAA content and cultivating the same. Educating people. Bringing socio-economic changes.

questions.question: In a 30-year-old woman with a body weight of 55 kg, what is the recommended daily protein intake?
questions.explanation: age, sex, physical activity level, and overall health. However, a commonly cited guideline is to consume around 0.8 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight per day. For a woman with a body weight of 55 kg, the recommended daily protein intake would be approximately 0.8 * 55 = 44 grams. This is very close to 45 grams. Incorrect Options: Option B - 55gm: This option is slightly higher than the commonly recommended 0.8 grams per kilogram. It's more than what is generally recommended for this person's body weight. Option C - 60gm: Similar to option B, this option is higher than the commonly recommended daily protein intake of 0.8 grams per kilogram for a person of this weight. Option D - 70gm: This option is significantly higher than the commonly recommended daily protein intake and is not in line with the 0.8 grams per kilogram guideline.

questions.question: Which of the following substances should be eaten to prevent thiamine deficiency?
questions.explanation: thiamine, whole grains and fortified products are better at preventing thiamine deficiency. Rice and wheat, when consumed in their whole form (i.e., brown rice and whole wheat), provide a better source of thiamine and can help in preventing thiamine deficiency compared to the other options listed. Incorrect Options: Option B - Curd: While curd (yogurt) is a good source of various nutrients, including calcium and protein, it is not a significant source of thiamine. It does not play a major role in preventing thiamine deficiency. Option C - Salad: Salads typically consist of vegetables and fruits, which can provide a range of vitamins and minerals. However, thiamine content in salads varies depending on the specific vegetables and fruits used. In general, salad is not a primary source of thiamine. Option D - Sabji (Aloo): Aloo (potato) is commonly used in sabji (vegetable dishes) and is a good source of thiamine compared to some other foods. However, for a more substantial prevention of thiamine deficiency, other foods rich in thiamine should be included.

questions.question: A man presented with bilateral swelling of his legs, diarrhoea, and dyspnea. He has a history of consuming mustard oil from a local vendor. Which test should be performed by the health inspector to check for the adulterant?
questions.explanation: suggests epidemic dropsy , commonly occurring when mustard oil is contaminated with argemone oil. Paper chromatography is the most sensitive test for detecting the presence of argemone oil in edible oils. It helps identify the adulterant based on the separation and visualization of specific components. Epidemic dropsy: Clinical features Bilateral leg swelling, diarrhoea, dyspnoea, features of glaucoma and heart failure even up to death. Causative agent Sanguinarine (toxic alkaloid present in argemone oil). Detection of contamination Nitric acid test: the presence of a red-brown ring when added to the sample oil indicates the presence of argemone oil. Paper chromatography test. Most sensitive and better than nitric acid test (Option A) (Option B ruled out) Prevention Accidental contamination: removing argemone weeds growing among oilseed crops. Deliberate contamination: enforcing Prevention of Food Adulteration Act. Methylene Blue Reduction Test (Option C): This test is used to measure the bacterial contamination of milk and is not relevant to detecting oil adulterants. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 27th edition, page 772

questions.question: Xeropthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of bitot spot is more than?
questions.explanation: prevalence of bitot spot is more than 0.5% Incorrect Options: 0.01% (Option A): Xeropthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of corneal xerosis/corneal ulceration/keratomalacia spot is more than 0.01% 0.05% (Option B): Xeropthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of corneal ulcer/scar is more than 0.05%. 1% (Option D): Xeropthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of night blindness is more than 1%. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 472

questions.question: A mother of a breastfeeding child only eats vegetables. Which deficiency is common in this case?
questions.explanation: predominantly present in animal sources. Cobalamin - vitamin B12 Sources Liver; Meat; Milk; Eggs; Cheese; Synthesised by gut bacteria (not found in food of vegetable origin) Absorption Absorbed in terminal ileum, bound to intrinsic factor. Uses It helps in the synthesis of fatty acid(myelin) and DNA. Deficiency Megaloblastic anemia Demyelinating lesion in the spinal cord Infertility Requirements Adults: 2-2 mcg/day. Pregnancy: extra 0.25 mcg. Lactation: extra 1 mcg. Infants and children: 1.2 mcg. Incorrect Options: Vitamin A (Option B): Vitamin A deficiency is ruled out as the cheapest source of vitamin A is from green leafy vegetables. Vitamin D (Option C): Vitamin D2 is derived from plant sources. Vitamin K (Option D): Vitamin K1 is derived from green vegetables. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 735 and 751

questions.question: Iron absorption is decreased in which of the following?
questions.explanation: haem-iron and non-haem iron. Haem iron Haem iron is better absorbed than non-haem iron. Found in liver, meat, poultry, and fish. Promotes absorption of non-haem iron in plant foods eaten concurrently. Non-Haem iron: It is found in plant-based foods such as cereals, green leafy vegetables, legumes, nuts, oilseeds, jaggery, and dried fruits. Additional Iron Sources : Cooking in iron vessels can significantly contribute to dietary iron in some areas. Iron Content in Milk : Low in all mammalian species. Breast milk contains less than 0.2 mg/dL but has good bioavailability. Bioavailability and Absorption Inhibitors : Non-haem iron absorption is hindered by phytates, oxalates, carbonates, phosphates, and dietary fibre. Foods like milk, eggs, and tea also inhibit iron absorption. Indian vegetarian diets often contain high levels of these inhibitors (e.g., phytates in bran, phosphates in egg yolk, tannin in tea, and oxalates in vegetables). Incorrect Options: Amla (Option A): Vitamin C in Amla is the promoter of iron absorption Sprouts (Option B): Sprouting promotes iron absorption. Lemon (Option D): Vitamin C in Lemon is the promoter of iron absorption Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 737

questions.question: What are the potential effects of folic acid deficiency during pregnancy?
questions.explanation: proper closure of the neural tube during early fetal development. If a pregnant woman does not have enough folic acid, it can lead to neural tube defects. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not caused by folic acid deficiency during pregnancy. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 783

questions.question: Which of the following mineral deficiency is associated with sexual dysfunction?
questions.explanation: can lead sexual infantilism in adolescents. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not associated with sexual dysfunction. Reference: .

questions.question: A 5-year-old has the following anthropometric findings: Weight/age < -3.2 SD, Height/age < -2.5 SD, Weight/height < -1.7 SD. Under which of the following categories would this child be classified?
questions.explanation: Severe underweight can result from chronic malnutrition because it reflects a long-term deficit in nutrient intake. Height/age < -2.5 SD : This indicates stunting. Stunting is a sign of chronic malnutrition, reflecting long-term inadequate nutrition and poor health conditions. Weight/height < -1.7 SD : This indicates wasting. Wasting is typically a sign of acute malnutrition, but in this context, it is less severe compared to the other measures. Given the severity of the indicators for weight/age and height/age, which are more pronounced, the primary issue appears to be chronic malnutrition. Incorrect Options: Option A - Acute malnutrition: Acute malnutrition is primarily indicated by significant wasting (weight/height < -2 SD). Although the child has wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD), the more severe indicators are weight/age and height/age, pointing more towards a chronic issue rather than an acute one. Acute on chronic malnutrition would be considered if both stunting (chronic) and wasting (acute) were severely present. In this case, the degree of wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD) is not as severe as the stunting and underweight indicators, which suggests that the primary issue is chronic. Option C - Acute on chronic malnutrition: Acute on chronic malnutrition would be considered if both stunting (chronic) and wasting (acute) were severely present. In this case, the degree of wasting (weight/height < -1.7 SD) is not as severe as the stunting and underweight indicators, which suggests that the primary issue is chronic. Option D - Severe malnutrition: Severe malnutrition is a general term and could refer to either acute or chronic malnutrition. While the child is indeed severely malnourished, specifying chronic malnutrition is more accurate given the primary indicators of weight/age and height/age. Reference: ..

questions.question: Wasting in a child is assessed by which of the following measures?
questions.explanation: wasting in a child. Wasting refers to a child who has a low weight compared to their height, indicating acute undernutrition. Weight-for-height assesses acute malnutrition (wasting). Height-for-age assesses chronic malnutrition (stunting). Weight-for-age is an overall indicator but does not differentiate between acute and chronic malnutrition, making it less specific for either. Head circumference is a general indicator that can reflect both acute and chronic malnutrition, but it's not the primary marker for either. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are not the key indicators for wasting. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 723

questions.question: In a 30-year-old male presenting with bleeding gums and iron deficiency anemia, which vitamin deficiency would you anticipate?
questions.explanation: symptoms such as bleeding gums, joint pain, and fatigue. Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to impaired connective tissue integrity, resulting in bleeding from the gums and other mucous membranes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is known to cause night blindness and can affect vision. It is not directly associated with bleeding gums or iron deficiency anemia. Option B - Vitamin B1: Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to conditions like beriberi, which primarily affects the nervous system and cardiovascular system. It is not directly linked to bleeding gums or iron deficiency anemia. Option D - Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can result in conditions like rickets or osteomalacia, affecting bone health. It is not typically associated with bleeding gums or iron deficiency anemia.

questions.question: A woman develops edema, visual disturbances, and heart failure after consuming a food item. What is the most likely adulterant?
questions.explanation: which is derived from the seeds of the Argemone Mexicana plant, which is a common weed in mustard fields, and its seeds can accidentally get mixed with mustard seeds during oil extraction. Consumption of mustard oil contaminated with Argemone oil leads to a condition known as epidemic dropsy. It can present as: Sudden bilateral non-inflammatory pitting edema. Diarrhoea Dyspnoea Cardiac defects Glaucoma Incorrect Options: BOAA (Option B): BOAA is a neurotoxic amino acid found in the seeds of the Lathyrus sativus plant and leads to neurolathyrism. Pyrrolizidine (Option C): Pyrrolizidine alkaloids are hepatotoxic compounds found in various plants. Chronic exposure leads to veno-occlusive disease of the liver, causing hepatomegaly, jaundice, and ascites Aflatoxin (Option D): Aflatoxin causes aflatoxicosis, which typically results in liver damage, hepatocellular carcinoma, and acute hepatic failure. Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 723

questions.question: In endemic area what will be the dose of Vitamin A for 1-6 year old baby?
questions.explanation: intervention in areas where vitamin A deficiency is endemic, as it helps prevent childhood blindness and reduce mortality rates. In regions with a high prevalence of vitamin A deficiency, the World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a high-dose vitamin A supplementation schedule for children aged 6 months to 5 years. Incorrect Options: Option B - 1 lakh IU orally for 6 months: It is not the recommended dose. The dose is typically higher. Option C - 2 lakh IU for 6 weeks: It is not in line with the standard supplementation schedule. The dose is given for a longer duration. Option D: 2 lakh IU for 1 year: It is not the recommended schedule. The supplementation period is shorter.

questions.question: Criteria of mid arm circumference in Shakir's tape for severe acute malnutrition ?
questions.explanation: in assessing nutritional status, especially in identifying severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children. Shakir's tape is a specific measuring tape used for this purpose. The measurement helps identify children who are at a higher risk of health complications due to malnutrition. Incorrect Options: Option B - <12.5: A MUAC measurement of less than 12.5 cm might be indicative of moderate acute malnutrition, but for severe acute malnutrition, the cutoff is generally lower. Option C - <13.5: A MUAC measurement of less than 13.5 cm might be used as a cutoff for moderate acute malnutrition, but for severe acute malnutrition, the cutoff is lower. Option D - <14.5 . A MUAC measurement of less than 14.5 cm might be used as a cutoff for moderate acute malnutrition, but for severe acute malnutrition, the cutoff is lower.

questions.question: A 3 year old child came in the opd with severe diarrhea , vomiting, skin, deeply sunken eyes and no urine output. On examination baby is severely dehydrated, lethargic,high respiratory rate and BP of 80/60mmHg. Which fluid is given for management?
questions.explanation: solution) is an intravenous fluid that contains a combination of electrolytes (sodium, potassium, calcium, and chloride) along with lactate. It is commonly used for fluid resuscitation and correction of electrolyte imbalances in cases of severe dehydration, hypovolemia, and shock. The balanced electrolyte composition of Ringer lactate makes it a suitable choice for managing the described severely dehydrated child with low blood pressure. Incorrect Options: Option A - ORS (Oral Rehydration Solution): ORS is a commonly used solution for rehydrating individuals with mild to moderate dehydration caused by diarrhea and vomiting. It contains a balanced mixture of electrolytes and glucose to replace lost fluids and electrolytes. However, in the described scenario where the child is severely dehydrated, lethargic, and has no urine output, oral rehydration alone might not be sufficient or feasible due to the child's condition. Option C - Normal Saline: Normal saline (0.9% sodium chloride) is an isotonic solution commonly used for fluid replacement in various clinical situations. While it can be used for fluid resuscitation, Ringer lactate is often preferred over normal saline due to its more balanced electrolyte composition, which closely resembles the body's natural electrolyte concentrations. Option D - Dextrose: Dextrose solutions (glucose solutions) provide energy and can be used in cases of low blood sugar levels (hypoglycemia). However, the primary concern in the described scenario is severe dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and hypovolemia. While dextrose can be added to IV fluids, it is not the primary solution of choice for fluid resuscitation in cases of severe dehydration.

questions.question: What concentration of fluoride is typically associated with causing crippling fluorosis?
questions.explanation: that results in significant disability. It typically occurs when the fluoride concentration in drinking water exceeds 10 mg/L. Fluoride (mg/L) Effects Less than 0.5 Dental cavities 0.5–1.0 Protection against dental cavities. Good for bone and teeth. 1.5–3.0 Dental fluorosis 3.0–10 Skeletal fluorosis 10 or more Crippling skeletal fluorosis and severe osteosclerosis Drinking Water Quality Aspect Recommended Value Microbiological Aspects Coliform Bacteria (E. coli) 0 coliforms per 100ml of potable water Chemical Properties Chlorides Maximum: 600 mg/L Hardness 100-300 mg/L Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) Less than 600 mg/L (good), permissible up to 1000 mg/L Lead 0.01 mg/L Fluoride 0.5-0.8 mg/L Nitrate < 50 mg/L Physical Properties Turbidity Up to 5 NTU (Nephelometric Turbidity Unit) Color Up to 15 TCU (True Color Unit) or 5 Hazen units Reference: Parks Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page no: 723, 848, 849

questions.question: The objective of the Mid Day Meal Programme is to provide additional support:
questions.explanation: approximately half of the protein requirements and one-third of the calorie requirements of the children. The meals provided through the program are designed to contribute to these nutritional needs. It was implemented to prevent school dropouts Incorrect Options: Option B . 1/3 protein and 1/3 calorie requirements: This option suggests that the Mid Day Meal Programme aims to supplement approximately one-third of both the protein and calorie requirements of the children. However, the actual goal of the program is to provide a higher proportion of protein to meet the nutritional needs adequately. Option C . 1/2 protein and 1/2 calorie requirements: This option states that the Mid Day Meal Programme aims to supplement approximately half of both the protein and calorie requirements of the children. However, the program's objective is to provide a higher proportion of protein to address protein deficiencies and promote healthy growth. Option D. 1/3 protein and 1/2 calorie requirements: This option implies that the Mid Day Meal Programme aims to supplement approximately one-third of the protein requirements and half of the calorie requirements of the children. However, the program aims to provide a higher proportion of protein to meet the nutritional needs effectively.

questions.question: What is the most commonly used method of pasteurization nowadays?

options.C: High temperature and short time method
options.D: Low temperature and long time method

questions.explanation: common pasteurization method. Pasteurization is a heat treatment process used to eliminate or reduce the presence of harmful microorganisms in food and beverages while maintaining their quality. There are different pasteurization methods, but the high temperature and short time method (also known as HTST or flash pasteurization) is the most widely employed method today. Milk is rapidly heated to a temperature of about 72 degree Celsius, is held at that temperature for not less than 15 seconds, and is then rapidly cooled to 4 degree Celsius. This method can pasteurize very large quantities of milk per hour. Incorrect Options: Option A . Holder (VAT) method: The Holder method, also known as the vat pasteurization method, involves heating milk or other liquids to a specified temperature and holding it at that temperature for a fixed duration. While this method was historically used, it is not as common today as the HTST method. Option B . Ultra high temperature method: The ultra-high temperature (UHT) method involves heating food or beverages to a very high temperature, typically above 135 degrees Celsius (275 degrees Fahrenheit), for a very short period, usually a few seconds. UHT pasteurization is commonly used for products that need extended shelf life without refrigeration. While the UHT method is widely used for some products, such as long-life milk, it is not the most common method overall. Option D . Low temperature and long time method: The low temperature and long time (LTLT) method, also known as batch pasteurization, involves heating milk or other liquids at lower temperatures for a longer duration compared to the HTST method. This method is commonly used for certain dairy products, such as artisanal or specialty cheeses, where maintaining the flavor and texture is crucial. However, it is not the most commonly used method in general food and beverage processing.

questions.question: Which vitamin is responsible for aiding in the absorption of iron?
questions.explanation: dietary components. Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, plays a crucial role in enhancing iron absorption from plant-based (non-heme) sources. Promoters of iron absorption: ascorbic acid and vitamin C-rich foods Eg. Amla, guava, citrus fruits etc. Incorrect Options: Option A . Vitamin A: Vitamin A does not directly enhance iron absorption. However, it is important for the overall health and functioning of the body, including the immune system and vision. Option B . Vitamin B: Vitamin B is a group of several different vitamins, including B1, B2, B6, and B12, among others. While vitamin B12 is involved in the production of red blood cells, it does not have a direct role in iron absorption. Option D . Vitamin E: Vitamin E does not have a significant impact on iron absorption. It primarily functions as an antioxidant, protecting cells from damage caused by free radicals.

questions.question: What is the cause of Wernicke encephalopathy?
questions.explanation: encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by a severe deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1). Thiamine is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in energy metabolism, particularly in the brain. Thiamine (vitamin B1) is essential for the normal functioning of the nervous system, including the brain. A deficiency of thiamine can lead to Wernicke encephalopathy, which is characterized by a triad of symptoms: confusion, ophthalmoplegia (paralysis or weakness of the eye muscles), and ataxia (loss of coordination). If left untreated, Wernicke encephalopathy can progress to a more severe and potentially life-threatening condition called Korsakoff syndrome. Incorrect Options: Option B . Biotin: Biotin (vitamin B7) deficiency can lead to various symptoms, including hair loss, skin rashes, and neurological problems. However, Wernicke encephalopathy specifically occurs due to a thiamine deficiency, not biotin. Option C . Niacin: Niacin (vitamin B3) deficiency can cause a condition called pellagra, which manifests as dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia, and other symptoms. While neurological symptoms can occur in pellagra, Wernicke encephalopathy is not directly associated with niacin deficiency. Option D . Hydroxycobalamin: Hydroxycobalamin (vitamin B12) deficiency can lead to a condition called pernicious anemia, which primarily affects the production of red blood cells. While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, Wernicke encephalopathy is not caused by a deficiency of hydroxycobalamin.

questions.question: What is the most effective way to assess chronic malnutrition in a child?
questions.explanation: height for age. Height for age, also known as stunting, is a commonly used indicator to assess chronic malnutrition in children. It measures the child's height in relation to their age and compares it to standardized growth charts or reference populations. This indicator provides valuable information about the child's long-term nutritional status and growth trajectory. Chronic malnutrition refers to the condition where a child experiences prolonged inadequate nutrient intake, which can lead to impaired growth and development. Height for age reflects the cumulative effects of undernutrition over time, indicating whether a child has experienced stunted growth compared to their peers of the same age. Incorrect Options: Option A . Weight for height: Weight for height, also known as wasting or acute malnutrition, is used to assess acute nutritional status and is more indicative of recent weight loss or inadequate weight gain. It is not the most appropriate indicator for evaluating chronic malnutrition. Option B: Weight for age: Weight for age is a commonly used indicator to assess underweight or general malnutrition. It compares a child's weight to the average weight of children of the same age. While it can provide insights into overall nutritional status, it is not specific to chronic malnutrition. Option D . Ponderal index: Ponderal index is calculated by dividing the weight in kilograms by the cube of the height in meters. It is used to assess body composition and can provide information about body proportionality. However, it is not specifically used to evaluate chronic malnutrition.

questions.question: What is the most effective treatment for idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura among the options provided?
questions.explanation: patients who do not respond to other treatments or who have chronic or recurrent ITP. The spleen is the primary site of platelet destruction in ITP, and removing it can help increase platelet counts and improve symptoms. Incorrect options: Option A - IV immunoglobulins: IV immunoglobulins (IVIG) are commonly used in the treatment of ITP, especially in acute cases or when immediate platelet count elevation is required. IVIG works by increasing the platelet count temporarily. Option B - Steroids: Steroids, such as prednisone, are often used as an initial treatment for acute ITP. Option D - Blood transfusion: Blood transfusion is not a primary treatment for ITP. May be used in specific cases. Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21e

questions.question: As per the recommended dietary allowance, what is the prescribed dosage of iodine for lactating women in India? µ g/day µ g/day µ g/day µ g/day
questions.explanation: µ g/day µ g/day- The recommended dose of iodine for lactating women in India, according to the recommended dietary allowance, is 280 µ g/day. Iodine is an essential mineral required for the synthesis of thyroid hormones. During pregnancy and lactation, the iodine requirement increases to support the growth and development of the fetus and the production of breast milk. Incorrect Options: Option A: 200 µ g/day- This dosage is lower than the recommended dietary allowance for lactating women in India. Option B: 220 µ g/day- This dosage is also lower than the recommended dietary allowance for lactating women in India. Option C: 250 µ g/day- This dosage is still lower than the recommended dietary allowance for lactating women in India. Reference: .

questions.question: What BMI value is generally considered extremely low and associated with a higher risk of severe health complications in men? a. BMI < 10 b. BMI < 15 c. d.
questions.explanation: value calculated based on an individual's weight and height. A BMI below 15 is considered extremely low and is associated with a significantly increased risk of severe health complications. This level of underweight can indicate malnutrition and a host of potential health problems, including: Weakened immune system: Malnutrition can lead to a compromised immune system, making the individual more susceptible to infections and diseases. Organ damage: Extremely low BMI can result in damage to vital organs, including the heart, liver, and kidneys, which can lead to organ failure. Nutritional deficiencies: Severely low BMI is often indicative of severe nutritional deficiencies, including deficiencies in essential vitamins and minerals. Muscle wasting: It can result in muscle wasting and overall weakness, affecting mobility and daily functioning. Increased risk of mortality: Extremely low BMI is associated with a significantly higher risk of mortality, especially if it is sustained over time. It's important to note that the specific threshold for severe health risk can vary depending on an individual's unique circumstances, such as age, underlying health conditions, and muscle mass. However, a BMI below 15 is generally considered a critical indicator of extreme underweight and associated health risks. It is important for individuals with such low BMIs to seek medical attention and nutritional support to address these health concerns. Options B, C, and D represent BMI values that are not considered extremely low, and they do not typically pose the same level of health risk associated with a BMI below 15. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following is not employed in evaluating body fat?
questions.explanation: used to assess body fat. Instead, it is a measurement used in the staging of melanoma, a type of skin cancer. The Breslow index quantifies the thickness of melanoma tumor cells within the skin, providing information about the cancer's severity and prognosis. It is unrelated to body fat assessment. Incorrect Options Option A: Quetelet's index- Also known as Body Mass Index (BMI), Quetelet's index is commonly used to assess body fatness in relation to weight and height. It is calculated by dividing a person's weight in kilograms by the square of their height in meters. BMI provides a general estimation of body fat levels and is widely used in population studies and clinical settings. Option B: Total body potassium- Although not directly used to measure body fat, total body potassium measurement can indirectly provide an estimate of lean body mass. Since potassium is primarily found within cells, the total body potassium content can be used as an indicator of the body's muscle mass. By subtracting lean body mass from total body weight, body fat mass can then be estimated. Option C: Total body water- Similar to total body potassium, measuring total body water is not a direct method for assessing body fat but is used to estimate body composition. By determining the amount of water present in the body, various equations can be applied to estimate fat-free mass, and subsequently, body fat mass.

questions.question: Normal Waist to hip-ratio in male is:
questions.explanation: 0.90. It is a measure of central obesity and is used as an indicator of increased health risks associated with excess abdominal fat. This ratio is calculated by dividing the circumference of the waist by the circumference of the hips. Incorrect options Option A: >0.8 in males This value is not within the normal range for waist-to-hip ratio. Option B: >0.85 in females This value refers to the normal waist-to-hip ratio in females, not males. Option C: >0.90 males This value is outside the normal range and indicates an increased risk of health problems. Reference: 1)Notes, 2) Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: What is the purpose of administering ORS plus Zinc to a patient from a rural village?
questions.explanation: salts and sugars to replace fluids and electrolytes lost during diarrhea. It is a well-established treatment for diarrhea and helps prevent dehydration in affected individuals. When ORS is combined with zinc supplementation, it has been found to have additional benefits in the management of diarrhea, especially in children. Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in various bodily functions, including immune function and growth. The combination of ORS and zinc has been shown to: Reduce the duration and severity of diarrhea episodes: Zinc supplementation along with ORS has been found to reduce the duration of diarrhea, leading to faster recovery. Improve overall treatment outcomes: The combination therapy has been associated with lower treatment failure rates and a reduced need for additional medical interventions. Support overall health and nutritional status: Zinc is important for proper growth and development, and its supplementation helps replenish zinc stores that may be depleted during diarrheal episodes. Therefore, ORS plus zinc is an effective approach in the management of diarrhea, particularly in children, as it not only helps rehydrate the body but also reduces the duration of the illness and improves overall treatment outcomes. Incorrect options: Option A . Reduces infection: While ORS plus zinc can support the body's overall immune function, it does not directly reduce the infection itself. It primarily focuses on rehydration and reducing the duration of diarrhea. Option B. Antispasmodic: Antispasmodic medications are used to relieve muscle spasms and cramping. ORS plus zinc does not have antispasmodic properties. Option D. Enhances sodium absorption: ORS itself is designed to help restore the balance of electrolytes, including sodium, in the body. Zinc supplementation in combination with ORS primarily contributes to reducing the duration of diarrhea, rather than specifically enhancing sodium absorption.

questions.question: Beri-Beri seen in?
questions.explanation: commonly associated with diets predominantly consisting of polished rice. Polished rice lacks the outer bran layer, which is rich in thiamine. Incorrect options Option A . Sorghum eaters: Sorghum is not typically associated with causing Beri-Beri. Option B . Wheat eaters: Wheat is not a common cause of Beri-Beri. Option D . Maize eaters: Maize (corn) is not a common cause of Beri-Beri.

questions.question: What is the recommended treatment for a 1-year-old patient diagnosed with Keratomalacia?
questions.explanation: corneal damage. The standard treatment for Keratomalacia is vitamin A supplementation. In this case, the correct treatment option is administering 1 Lac IU (International Units) of vitamin A three times. Incorrect option: Option A . 1 Lac IU once: Vitamin A supplementation in Keratomalacia requires multiple doses to replenish the deficient levels adequately. Option C. 2 Lac IU once: A single high dose is not the recommended treatment approach for Keratomalacia. Option D. 2 Lac IU three times: This dosage is higher than the recommended treatment regimen for Keratomalacia. Reference: .

questions.question: How does the protein content of human milk compare to that of cow milk?
questions.explanation: to cow milk. Human milk and cow milk have different compositions to meet the nutritional needs of their respective species. Human Milk: Human milk is specifically designed to meet the nutritional requirements of human infants. It contains a lower protein content compared to cow milk. On average, human milk contains approximately 1 gram of protein per 100 milliliters. Cow Milk: Cow milk is intended to provide the necessary nutrients for the growth and development of calves. It has a higher protein content compared to human milk. Cow milk typically contains around 3-4 grams of protein per 100 milliliters. The lower protein content in human milk is appropriate for the digestive capabilities and growth patterns of human infants. Human milk is easier to digest, and the lower protein content ensures that infants' kidneys are not burdened with excessive protein metabolism.

questions.question: According to WHO, marker for obesity Index is:
questions.explanation: Organization (WHO). The Quetelet index, also known as the Body Mass Index (BMI), is a widely used measurement to assess obesity and overweight in individuals. Here's why it is considered the marker for obesity index according to WHO: BMI Calculation: The Quetelet index or BMI is calculated by dividing an individual's weight in kilograms by the square of their height in meters (BMI = weight in kg / height in meters²). This index provides a numerical value that correlates with body fatness and is commonly used to classify individuals into different categories, such as underweight, normal weight, overweight, and obesity. Accepted International Standard: The BMI has been adopted as an international standard by various health organizations, including the WHO. It is widely used as a screening tool for assessing the prevalence of overweight and obesity in populations and for monitoring trends over time. Health Risk Assessment: The BMI is considered an indicator of body fatness and is associated with various health risks. Higher BMI values are generally associated with an increased risk of chronic conditions such as cardiovascular diseases, type 2 diabetes, certain cancers, and musculoskeletal disorders. Other options are incorrect Reference: .

questions.question: A community medicine student was required to discuss the various natural sources of Vitamin A. Among the options listed below, which one offers the highest concentration of Vitamin A naturally?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B. Halibut liver oil Explanation: Among the options provided, halibut liver oil offers the highest concentration of naturally occurring Vitamin A. Halibut liver oil contains a significant amount of naturally occurring Vitamin A. Fish liver oils, including halibut liver oil, are rich sources of preformed Vitamin A (retinol), which is readily absorbed by the body. Option A. Carrot: Carrots are a good source of beta-carotene, a precursor to Vitamin A. However, the conversion of beta-carotene to active Vitamin A in the body is limited. Option C. Cod fish oil: Similar to halibut liver oil, cod fish oil is also a good source of preformed Vitamin A. It provides a concentrated form of Vitamin A. Option D. Cow milk: Cow milk contains Vitamin A, but it is usually in the form of beta-carotene. While milk can contribute to Vitamin A intake, it's not as concentrated a source as fish liver oils in providing preformed Vitamin A. Reference: .

questions.question: Which is the most suitable indicator to determine the nutritional value of protein?
questions.explanation: value of protein. Serum albumin concentration is commonly used as an indicator of protein nutritional status and is often included in assessments of overall nutritional status. Here's why it is considered the best index for calculating the nutrient value of protein: Protein Transport and Function: Albumin is the most abundant protein in the blood and plays a crucial role in transporting nutrients, including amino acids, hormones, and fatty acids, throughout the body. It also contributes to maintaining oncotic pressure and regulating fluid balance. Monitoring serum albumin concentration provides insights into the body's protein status and its ability to maintain these essential functions. Long Half-Life: Serum albumin has a relatively long half-life of about 20 days. This means that changes in serum albumin concentration reflect more prolonged changes in protein intake and synthesis rather than short-term fluctuations. It allows for a more accurate assessment of the long-term protein nutritional status of an individual. Availability of Laboratory Tests: Measuring serum albumin concentration is a relatively straightforward and widely available laboratory test. It can be easily performed using routine blood tests, making it a practical and cost-effective measure for evaluating protein nutritional status. Incorrect Option: Option B . Arm-muscle circumference: Arm-muscle circumference is often used as an indicator of muscle mass and can be affected by factors other than protein intake, such as physical activity and body fat percentage. It does not directly measure protein nutritional status or provide information about protein synthesis or breakdown. Option C . Creatinine-height index: The creatinine-height index is used to estimate muscle mass and assess muscle wasting. It is primarily used in specific clinical settings, such as in patients with kidney disease, and is not a direct measure of protein nutritional status or the nutrient value of protein intake. Option D . Serum transferrin level: Serum transferrin is a protein involved in iron transport. While it can provide information about iron status and iron deficiency, it is not specific to protein nutritional status or the overall nutrient value of protein intake.

questions.question: Keshan's disease is caused by a lack of
questions.explanation: inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis), primarily affecting children and young women. It was first identified in Keshan County, China, hence the name. The main cause of Keshan's disease is believed to be a deficiency of selenium, an essential trace element. Selenium is an important component of several enzymes involved in antioxidant defense mechanisms and the maintenance of heart muscle function. When selenium levels are low, the heart becomes more susceptible to damage from free radicals and viral infections. This can lead to myocarditis and subsequent heart failure, which are the hallmark features of Keshan's disease. Incorrect choices: Option B: Zinc: Zinc deficiency can lead to various health problems, but it is not directly associated with Keshan's disease. Zinc is involved in many physiological processes, including immune function, growth, and development. Option C: Copper: Copper deficiency can cause a range of symptoms, including anemia and neurological abnormalities, but it is not implicated in the development of Keshan's disease. Copper is essential for the synthesis of hemoglobin and the functioning of several enzymes. Option D: Iron: Iron deficiency is commonly associated with anemia, but it is not the cause of Keshan's disease. Iron is necessary for the production of hemoglobin, which carries oxygen in the blood.

questions.question: What type of anemia is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B12?
questions.explanation: type of anemia is characterized by red blood cells that are larger than normal (macrocytic) and have reduced hemoglobin content (hypochromic). Vitamin B12 is essential for the production of healthy red blood cells. It plays a key role in the synthesis of DNA and in the maturation of red blood cells in the bone marrow. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can result in ineffective DNA synthesis and impaired maturation of red blood cells, leading to the characteristic features of macrocytic hypochromic anemia. Incorrect Options Option A . Microcytic hypochromic anemia (choice A) is typically associated with iron deficiency anemia, where red blood cells are smaller and have reduced hemoglobin content. Option C . Normocytic normochromic anemia (choice C) refers to anemia with normal-sized red blood cells and normal hemoglobin content. It can be caused by various factors such as chronic diseases, kidney problems, and bone marrow disorders. Option D . None of the above is an incorrect answer as B is the correct answer Reference: .

questions.question: What methods would you employ to identify Vitamin A Deficiency in a school setting?
questions.explanation: the identification of clinical signs and symptoms associated with the deficiency. One of the early signs of Vitamin A deficiency is night blindness, which refers to the inability or difficulty to see in low light conditions or at night. Night blindness occurs due to the impaired functioning of the retina, which is responsible for vision in dim light. By asking individuals, particularly school children, about their ability to see in low light conditions or at night, healthcare providers or school health personnel can screen for the presence of night blindness. Children who report difficulties with night vision are likely to have an underlying Vitamin A deficiency. Incorrect Options Option A. Retinol: Retinol is a form of Vitamin A, but it is not a specific screening method for Vitamin A deficiency. Retinol levels can be measured in blood samples to assess overall Vitamin A status, but this is not typically used as a screening tool in a school setting. Option C. Carotene: Carotene, a precursor to Vitamin A, can be found in certain foods such as carrots, sweet potatoes, and leafy greens. However, assessing carotene levels is not a practical screening method for Vitamin A deficiency in a school setting. Option D. Bitot spots: Bitot spots are a clinical manifestation of Vitamin A deficiency and appear as foamy, white patches on the conjunctiva of the eye. While the presence of Bitot spots may indicate Vitamin A deficiency, their detection requires a close examination of the eyes, which may not be feasible in a school screening scenarioC Reference: .

questions.question: In Marasmus, the mid-arm muscle circumference is less than:
questions.explanation: characterized by overall wasting and severe weight loss, the MUAC measurement is significantly reduced. The cut off value for MUAC in Marasmus is generally set at 11.5 mm or less. Therefore, in the given options, the correct answer is 11.5. A MUAC measurement less than 11.5 cm indicates severe wasting and is consistent with the diagnosis of Marasmus. Incorrect Options : The incorrect choices B, C, and D are higher values and do not reflect the significant wasting and severe weight loss observed in Marasmus. MUAC values of 17, 19, or 21 cm would indicate a healthier or more normal nutritional status, rather than the characteristic feature of Marasmus. Reference: Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: What is the value of MAC in cases of severe malnutrition?
questions.explanation: WHO guidelines. A MAC measurement of 11.5 cms or less would indeed indicate severe malnutrition. Mid-upper arm circumference (MAC) is a commonly used anthropometric measurement to assess nutritional status, particularly for identifying severe malnutrition in children. MAC provides an estimate of muscle and fat stores in the upper arm and is an indicator of body composition and nutritional reserves. In severe malnutrition, the MAC measurement is typically below a certain cutoff point. The World Health Organization (WHO) defines a MAC of less than 11.5 cms as a criterion for severe acute malnutrition in children aged 6-59 months. Incorrect Options: Option A: 14.5 cms A MAC measurement of 14.5 cms would not be indicative of severe malnutrition. This value is within the normal range and does not suggest severe wasting or nutritional deficiency. Option B: 13.5 cms Similar to the previous choice, a MAC measurement of 13.5 cms would still fall within the normal range and would not indicate severe malnutrition. Option C: 12.5 cms MAC equal to or greater than 125 mm(12.5cms ) indicates No Acute Malnutrition Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM): MAC less than 115 mm. Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM): MAC between 115 mm and 125 mm. Reference: 1)Notes, 2) Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: Deficiency of Vitamin B12 leads to what type of anemia?
questions.explanation: deficiency leading to macrocytic hypochromic anemia. Other manifestations include: Pernicious anemia Peripheral neuropathy Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord. Incorrect options: Option A. Normochromic means that the cell is of normal color. Normocytic means the blood cell is of normal size. In vitamin B12 deficiency, neither of these happens. Option B . Microcytic means the blood cells are very small in size. In vitamin B12 deficiency, the blood cells produced are extremely large compared to the normal size. Option D. One of the options is right. Reference: Prep Ladder Video Based Notes

questions.question: What is the most prevalent cause of macrocytic anemia among the options provided?
questions.explanation: where the red blood cells (RBCs) are larger than normal. Alcohol use accounts for the majority, followed by deficiencies in folate and vitamin B12 and medications. Autoimmune causes are more common in middle-aged women. Hypothyroidism and primary bone marrow disease account for more cases of macrocytic anemia in older patients. Incorrect choices Option A : Vitamin B12 - this is 2nd most common cause. Option b: Bone marrow disorders: Bone marrow disorders like myelodysplastic syndrome can cause macrocytic anemia, but they are less common. Option d: Drug-induced: Certain medications, like chemotherapy and anticonvulsants, can cause macrocytic anemia, but they are not as common. Reference: .

questions.question: On ocular examination, a teenage girl with low body weight is observed to have the following finding. Which WHO grade corresponds to this finding?
questions.explanation: Bitot's spots, which are a sign of vitamin A deficiency. Bitot's spots are characterized by small, raised, foamy patches on the conjunctiva, and are graded as 1B by the WHO. Incorrect choices: Option a : A normal optic disc that shows no signs of damage or abnormalities is referred to as WHO grade 1A. The optic disc, which is located where the optic nerve enters and leaves the eye, is in charge of carrying visual data from the eye to the brain. A grade 1A finding denotes the absence of any signs of disease or damage to the optic disc, and the likelihood that the visual function is normal. Option c: Individuals with mild visual impairment are given the WHO grade 2A. In their better eye, people with 2A visual impairment have a visual acuity between 6/18 and 6/24 after correction (such as glasses or contact lenses), according to the WHO. Option d: The WHO classifies moderate visual impairment as grade 2B. It is indicated by a central visual field diameter of less than 20 degrees in the better eye, or by visual acuity in the better eye ranging from 6/18 to 6/60 (inclusive). As a result, while someone with a 2B visual impairment may be able to see some detail, their visual field is constrained, and they may find it difficult to perform tasks that call for fine visual discrimination or mobility. Reference: .

questions.question: Which of the following options can be employed for the treatment of Kesari dal toxicity?
questions.explanation: and other countries. When consumed in large quantities over time, the dal contains a neurotoxin called beta-N-oxalyl-L-alpha-beta diaminopropionic acid (BOAA), which can cause a neurological disorder called lathyrism. Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, plays a role in lathyrism due to its potential protective effects against the toxic effects of β -ODAP. β -ODAP is known to induce oxidative stress and damage to neurons. Vitamin C is an antioxidant that can counteract oxidative stress by neutralizing harmful free radicals and protecting cells from damage. Incorrect choices Option a : Some evidence suggests that sodium bicarbonate may exacerbate the effects of Kesari dal toxicity. This is due to the fact that bicarbonate can increase ODAP absorption from the gastrointestinal tract and thus increase its toxicity. As a result, using sodium bicarbonate to treat Kesari dal toxicity is generally not advised. Option b: There is no evidence that vitamin A has any effect on Kesari dal toxicity or Lathyrism. However, adequate vitamin A intake is required for healthy vision, immune system function, and cell growth and differentiation. Option d : Kesari Dal toxicity is not treated with IV immunoglobulin because it is not a viral or immune-mediated condition. It is most commonly used to treat autoimmune and immune-mediated disorders, as well as some cases of primary immunodeficiency disorders. Reference: .

questions.question: What is the cause of the 40-year-old female patient's acute onset leg swelling and loose stools, considering her family members also have similar symptoms and mustard oil is a regular part of their diet?
questions.explanation: which may lead to epidemic dropsy. MOA of Sanguinarine It inhibits oxidation of pyruvic acid which leads to accumulation of pyruvic acid in the blood. Clinical features of epidemic dropsy: Sudden bilateral non inflammatory pitting edema. Diarrhoea Dyspnoea Cardiac defects Glaucoma, thereby leads to death. Incorrect choices Option a : Clavine alkaloids are a type of natural compound found in plants, fungi, and animals. They have a variety of effects on the body, depending on the compound and the dose. Consumption of clavine alkaloids from contaminated grains, such as rye infected with the fungus Claviceps purpurea, can result in ergotism. Ergotism symptoms include vasoconstriction, gangrene, hallucinations, convulsions, and death. Option c : BOAA are toxic substances found in other plants, but they are not commonly associated with the symptoms described in this scenario. Option d: Pyrrolizidine alkaloids: causes Endemic Ascites Occur due to pyrrolizidine alkaloids which are derived from crotalaria plant (commonly used in MP & central parts in different food items)
